moves.1... d5: One of the most popular replies.
moves.5. Nc3: Putting pressure on the d5 pawn.
moves.5... Bb4 6. Bd2 Bxc3: Some think prefer the bishop over knight, thus not liking this move. I see no problem with it.
moves.8. Qb3: Threatening Qxb7, which I now realize only wins a pawn after Bxf3 9. Qxb7 Nbd7 10. gxf3.
moves.9... Nc6 10. O-O-O a5: I think black should be trying to find a way to threaten the knight on f3, not wasting moves like this.
moves.11. Qb5 Qd7 12. h3: Not wanting the bishop pinning my knight anymore, I threaten the bishop and force it to swap or retreat.
moves.14. g4: g5 threatens the knight protecting the pawn on d5, then I can win the pawn.
moves.14... Nb4: Queen swap or free pawn… Or both.
moves.15... Qxb5 16. cxb5 Na2+: Meh. After capturing the bishop I will no longer have doubled pawns on the b-file, because I will win take the knight with my pawn on b2.
moves.18... Rfc8 19. c4: Good move, the pinned pawn is under pressure.
moves.20. g5: After the knight retreating, I will eliminate the pawn on c6 and win the pawn on d5, and if the pawn on e6 takes back I will capture it, pinning rook to rook.
moves.22. cxd5 Rc3: I will receive another free pawn.
moves.23. dxe6: Beautiful. The pawn threatens the knight and the bishop threatens the rook.
moves.23... Rd8 24. exd7 Rxd7: I am now in a very good position.
moves.25... Rcc7 26. Rdc1 h6 27. Be4: I don't know why I did this.
moves.29. Rc1: Wanting to get rid of all the rooks and dominate with minor pieces.
moves.29... Rxc1 30. Kxc1 g6: With doubled up pawns, It is now pretty much a bishop, a king and five pawns against a king and four and a half pawns.
moves.31. Kc2: Wanting to get my king into the action. The most important and protected piece is deadly in the endgame.
moves.32. Bd5+ Kf8 33. Kb3: Wanting the pawns on b6 and a5.
moves.33... Ke7: The king can only defend one of the groups: g5, f5 and g6 or: a5 and b6.
moves.34. Ka4 Kd6: The king goes for the smaller group.
moves.35. Bf7: The pawn is unable to be saved, and my opponent resigns.
